div.p: All people are individuals that act in Hârnworld. They, particularly PCs, are at the core of what these rules are all about. Apart of the numerical attributes, a few of the only descriptive aspects should be mentioned.

Attributes are values that other people "attribute" to individuals they encounter, particularly those that they interact with for some time. The following lists those properties and the common values used for them.

Individuals should have a moral compass. Morality is a measure of unselfishness. The following serves as a guideline of the diversity found in Hârnworld, but is by no means exhaustive. Sindarin tend towards the “higher” moral standards.

Customary description of Morality include: Diabolical, Unscrupulous, Corruptible, Law-Abiding, Principled, Exemplary. They are not always applied correctly when dealing with enemies or friends. Moral description from others tend to be worse when describing an enemy.
People have a descriptive sexuality. The distribution of sexuality in Hârn is roughly 90% heterosexual, 5% bi-sexual and 5% homosexual. Other forms of sexuality may exist but are hidden.

Although Hârn has many exotic creatures, Humans, Sindarin and Khuzdul are by far the most commonly encountered. The population distribution on Hârn is approximately Human (97%), Sindarin (1%), and Khuzdul (1%).
Among encountered humans 48% are male, among Sindarin 45%, and among Khuzdul 75%. (Other individuals encountered are female.)

Every day of the year (360) has an equal probability of being the birthday of a random person. In other words: they are evenly distributed. Names of calendar months are readily available in other sections of Hârnworld.

Sunsign is a major factor for skill-affinity, but all sunsigns have advantages and disadvantages. Sunsign is determined by birthdate. The first two and last two days of each sign are termed the cusp: a person born on the 1st of Ilvin is termed a Tai-Skorus Cusp (the actual sunsign is named first). Those born on the cusp enjoy the benefits of either sign. Hârnic astrology reveals the Pvaric nature of Kelestia. Personality descriptions for each of the twelve signs of the zodiac are given in HârnPlayer. The personality of a person born on the cusp would be a blend of the two signs.
HârnWorld regional modules provide Birthplace generation tables. The GM may assign you a birthplace, or tell you what dice to roll to generate one on these tables.
A person’s Culture is determined by Birthplace. Most people born on Hârn are Feudal. Common exceptions are: Imperial (Tharda), Viking (Orbaalese), Tribal, Sindarin, and Khuzan.

The Social Class is usually not something considered random. The table shows the distribution of all classes, should a hypothetical census be taken. It may be useful to determine the Social Class of a randomly encountered individual. For some cultures a random result does not make sense (e.g. Slaves in Kaldor). Refer to the relevant HârnWorld publication.

About a third of all individuals encountered are first-born. Of the remainder, a third is a second-born and so on. For Sindarin and Khuzdul 50% are first-born and of the remainder, 50% are second-born instead. The sex and age of each sibling may be determined accordingly, with a 60% of each still being alive. To determine the number of siblings, determine the rank of the last sibling as before, but which obviously must come after the indiviual's rank already determined.
The individual’s Father and Mother represent an important aspect of an individual in a mostly feudal society.

ul.li: 50% of all people are regular offspring, the person is raised by his natural parents. Of these cases, when a minor comes of age, 60% see both parents alive and living together, 20% see either the father or the mother absent (desertion, divorce, etc.). In the remaining 20% either the father or mother is dead, in half of the cases the surviving spouse has remarried.

20% of all people were fostered; they lived with another family for social, economic, or political reasons. Guilded apprentices are usually fostered with their masters, as are squires training for knighthood. Poor families, especially those with only one parent, commonly foster one or more children with a relative or neighbor. Fostered children are usually aware of their parents’ identity.

5% of individuals were adopted by another family for social, economic, or political reasons. Adoption is generally only done if both parents are dead, but there are exceptions if parental consent is given. Adopted children are often unaware of the fact.

15% are Bastards. Parents never married, most likely because the father was of a higher social class, or one (or both) parents were already married or betrothed. Acknowledgement happens only in a third of all cases. A bastard usually lives with his mother, but may reside with father if acknowledged.

10% of people are orphans, both father and mother are deceased. Only 5% of orphans live alone, the others are either Fostered with another family/clan (80%) or adopted by another family/clan (15%). Brothers and sisters (if any) may have been fostered/adopted by another family.

div.p: It is the habit of the upper classes to spread their oats throughout the lower classes; if unacknowledged, the real father may never be known, but then again, he may be someone of wealth and power who could be helpful. Acknowledging a bastard is a significant act; the admission can have important emotional ramifications for both parents, especially to their respective spouses. In families where there is property and/or titles to inherit, acknowledged bastards usually follow the youngest legitimate heir, but dynamic characters may do better, especially if they happen to be a father’s eldest son and the legitimate heirs are weak. Many a dynastic bonfire has been ignited with such a spark.

Estrangement measures a person’s popularity in the clan, tribe, and/or family. It has a significant effect on opportunities, including any inheritance. Being the eldest child of a knight is less advantageous if he hates you. Siblings with different estrangements are often jealous of each other; this can produce interesting family politics.

ul.li: 10% are outcasts. They are ignored or may even be attacked by other family members. Of eldest children, only 5% are outcasts, and in small clans any child has only a 1% chance of being outcast.
30% are unpopular. With the likely exception of the mother, the family dislikes the person. Any birthright is/was given grudgingly, if at all. In small clans this happens only a 20% of the time.
35% are popular with their clan.
5% are treated as favorites. The individual has privileges, possibly at the expense of other siblings. Of eldest children, 10% are favorite. In small clans, 24% of offspring is treated favoringly.

div.p: A person’s relationship to the Clanhead is often more important than to parents. Hârnic clans tend to be large. Some live in close proximity. Some number in the thousands and are widely dispersed. Wealthy and noble clans are often extended. Poor clans are likely to be smaller, especially if they live in major settlements. Poor families in the same town or district may have the same clan name, but have been out of touch for generations. Except for outcast characters, the clanhead can always provide shelter and a hot meal. In some cultures, maternal relationships are more important.
The hypothetical census would have for a person: 15% father or mother as the clan head, 10% a cousin, 25% an aunt or uncle. All others (50%) identify the clanhead as distant.

The average height of a Hârnic male human is 68 inches with a variance of 5.83. The average is modified: Sindarin: -3", Khuzdul: -14". Human females: -2", Sindarin females: 1". Ivinian +1”, nobility +2”, urban poor -2”. Such measurements are often made by Physicians, while averages and variance thereof are only calculated by excentric scholars.
On Hârn, the "optimal" weight of a person depends on his height and is determined by the Physician's Guild and usually published in a yearly almanach.

The Clothiers' Guild and others have agreed on a size measure that relates to weight and is only a scale from 1-10. The apparent distribution of sizes is recorded here. Items that are too small or too big cause discomfort. A one size difference may be acceptable. The distribution was calculated on the human population alone. Non-humans were too rare, when the data was sampled, but their sizes have been standardized by the guild none-the-less.

Frame is another proportional attribute mainly used by Clothiers. It is measured in five main categories. It is determined by the actual instead of the optimal weight to height ratio. The optimal Weight : Height ratio is considered 100%.
Complexion is the color of a person’s skin. Human is for all people of Hârnic ancestry. Nordic humans are similar to Khuzdul.
A person’s attractiveness to the same species. Comeliness can be modified by cosmetics, but these enhancements usually wear off after some time. The courtesan's guild maintains these statistics.

Physical ability is assessed by the military (including their physicians) and a five-star rating is used. Non-humans often have their own physiology - that is recognized in the statistics. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Agility moves the body. Agility is useful for warriors, seamen, and dancers.
Dexterity is the ability to manipulate objects with the hands. Dexterity is important for warriors and cut-purses.
Stamina is the general physiological condition. Stamina determines for how long wound healing takes and also affects disease and poison resistance.

Strength is sheer physical power, a crucial attribute for combat and other physical activities, which is why military types usually assess it. It is common knowledge that additional weight leads to increased strength. However, this has not been measured accurately and not any weight leads to an increase in strength. It is also unknown whether the same relationship to weight exists for Sindarin and Khuzdul.

Physicians collect the data for the senses, often diseases or poisons affect the senses and their origin can be determined by gauging their effects. A five-star rating is used. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Eyesight is the ability to see in daylight. Except for nocturnal creatures (like Gargun) eyesight is reduced in the dark and that affects all activity requiring vision.
Hearing is used to sense sound. This is essential for musicians.
Smell estimates sensitivity to odor and taste. This can be useful for hunting and/or tracking, and may warn of danger. Of course, in a medieval town, a keen sense of smell may well be a curse.
The pleasantness and/or volume of a person’s voice. Excellent and unearthly voices are in high demand. The scale is provided by the Sindarin.

Some people have one or more Medical Traits, or diseases, scars, and other identifying marks acquired during life. The Sindarin are immune to human diseases, but more are considered “Sterile” than other species. The list is not complete and no prevalence statistics in the populace are given.

ul.li: Addiction: Individuals consume some substance like alcohol or a drug. The urge is hard to overcome in certain situations. When under the influence, people may become unconscious, injure themselves, etc.
Albinism: Pallid complexion, white hair, red eyes. Viewing bright light causes intense eye pain. Albinos sunburn very easily. Some people consider them very attractive.

Allergy: Common allergies are to pollen, hair, fur, feathers, wool, bee stings, or to foods such as eggs, milk, cereals, or shellfish. When the substance is nearby, a person suffers from sneezing, wheezing, and coughing. This results in reduced abilities until the allergy source is avoided or removed. Eating allergic foods can cause serious illness or death - consider this as poison.
Ambidextrous: can use both hands equally well.
Arm missing or deformed: Activities which require two hands (such as shooting a bow, or using a shield and weapon) are impossible.
Birthmark(s): may impact Comeliness, or indicate a special ancestry.
Dwarfism: Height is Species minimum minus 2-12 inches, with Heavy Frame.
Epilepsy: Individual may have a seizure if traumatized. Swimming and Riding should be avoided.
Ear: One ear is missing or deaf.
Eye: One eye is missing or blind. Lack of depth perception and reduced field of vision makes some activities difficult.
Gigantism: Individual height is Species maximum plus 2-12 inches, with Massive Frame.
Hemophilia: Blood clots much more slowly than normal. Females do not suffer the effect, but pass it on to their sons.
Hirsutism: Excessive body hair. Such a person may be mistaken for Gargun or were-creature.
Leg: One leg is missing or deformed. Such an individual can only move at 1/3 sprint speed with the use of a peg-leg.
Left-Handed: People with this "affliction" are likely to suffer some discrimination.
Leprosy: Body covered with sores/scabs. Pain sensitivity is reduced. Comliness is reduced. Leprosy is contagious.
Lycanthropy: The individual is a were-creature. Some Physicians consider this an imaginary disease, used by miscreants to scare gullible people.
Monochromasia: Severe color blindness. All colors are perceived as shades of gray.
Obesity: A person’s weight is 50% to 100% more than optimal.
Parasites: Worms, fleas, lice, etc. These are fairly common among the lower classes. Such individuals have special difficulties with social activity.
Poxmarks (healed): A person may bear scars from a disease such as smallpox.
Scars: Invariably reduces Comeliness.
Sterile: The person cannot have children.

div.p: Shek-P'var and Priests collect the statistics for these attributes. They are not willingly shared, only few scholars have access to the combined treasure of these numbers. A five-star rating is used. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Intelligence is the ability to reason and articulate. Often the following descriptions are used for the star scale:

ul.li: * = Absent-minded, moronic, stupid
** = Forgetful, slow-witted
*** = Average
**** = Good memory, clever
***** = Excellent memory, genius

div.p: Aura is Psionic concept. Hârnic philosophers believe that all living things have Aura and that the physical body is simply a place where the immortal spirit currently resides. High Aura indicates high psychic ability, and is the most important attribute for Psionics and magic (although Will and Intelligence are also vital).

Will encapsulates mental strength, tenacity, and patience. A person with low Will lacks confidence, panics easily, and has difficulty with tedious tasks. Those with high Will are resolute, confident, and stubborn.

Phobias, manias, and other mental disorders can be disruptive. The list of mental disorders is not comprehensive. Mental disorders of the same type may have different severities. A phobia is an irrational fear/aversion. When likely to be stimulated by an appropriate situation, a person's Will is tested to determine if the phobia can be resisted or not. If relief is impossible, the person may faint, become hysterical, go berserk, etc. A mania is an irrational fascination, obsession, or compulsion, usually to excess. An individual with Pyromania takes every opportunity to start a fire; with Hydrophobia he is unlikely to enjoy swimming, boating, etc. Severity of the disorder is, of course, relevant in the actions that are taken. Some disorders are only latent and the level of Severity is unknown. It is quite possible for someone with Acrophobia to climb a mountain with no problems, but panic sitting atop a twenty feet wall. Phobias are irrational.

The list is compiled by specialized physicians but also by Savorya Shek P'var. A prevalence is not given, nor is the chance of multiple disorders given. The list is considered harmful, if it were to leak into the public. Translations are available for physicians not versed in scholarly tongues but sufficient funds.

div.p: * The person may change personality in stressful situations, based on his Will. The primary personality is neurotic and totally unaware of the secondary personality. The latter, on the other hand, is aware of the primary personality and often takes desperate actions to try and overcome the neurosis of that personality.

Gods or goddesses may be worshiped (however laxly) by any person. While people may respect and acknowledge the existence of any number of deities, they usually only follow one, although it is possible to change religion. The religion a person may encounter depend on a lot of circumstances and depends on the birthplace. Available choices are presented in other Hârnworld publications, which also consider culture and social class. Most people tend to follow the deity of their parents or guardians.

While there are chivalrous worshipers of Morgath and corrupt Laranians, people tend to be more satisfied if their morals matches that of their deity. Churches and clerics, unaware of an individual’s true morality, may be fooled.

People may faithfully ascribe to two or more religions, provided the deities are not diametrically opposed. Some miscreants may try to subvert an opposing religion, but this is not faithful. Some rare people may consider themselves godless. Divine intervention is another word for miracle. However, the acts of deities should never be confused with spells, which are the acts of mages.

An occupation largely determines the skills a person learns during adolescense and the opportunities that follow, at least initially. Occupation is not necessarily a life commitment. Jobs can change during a life, although this might involve lengthy re-training. The occupations available depend mainly on Social Class, although birthplace and natural talent (attributes) may open or close some doors. Some vocations (Knight and Herald) are only available to high-born individuals; some require exceptional natural talent. Birthplace is also relevant; a person born in land-locked Kaldor may have a hard time running away to the sea.

Determining the chances for the occupation of a random individual is hard, since no such census data is available. The outcome would largely depend on Social Class, which depends on the occupation of one’s parents. Some children follow the same occupation or choose another at GM discretion. The eldest born survivor, especially if a favorite, would be expected to follow the family occupation. Later born offspring have more choice, especially if unpopular. As a reference, the occupations a person can choose in Hârnic society are listed, with average income and years of apprenticeship.

Guilded Occupations: Wages given are for Bonded Masters; room and board may also be provided. The employer would bear the additional cost of providing materials and supplies, but tools are owned by the master. A skilled mason-architect building a new castle, or an exquisite sword craftsman, could earn fees up to six times higher, but such incomes are rare. Apprentices receive room & board and sometimes get pocket money from generous masters. Journeymen receive 30-60% of a master's wages, depending on experience, plus room and board. Freemasters have variable incomes because demand for their services can vary. See: HârnPlayer, page 15.

Unguilded Occupations: Wages given are for average experienced workers; others might earn more/less depending on skills. Wages are dependent on the availability of labor. They also tend to be higher in summer and lower in winter.

Occupational rating is on the typical five-star scale. When completing an apprenticeship, a person is assumed to have advanced to *** (three stars) through his training. The occupation of the parent will usually convey a * (one star) rating. Attributes play a role in selecting a suitable profession. There are practical and common sense limits. A warrior with a sufficiently high Aura can certainly learn spells, but doing so requires years learning the mysteries and ways of magic.

A simple peasant may possess little more the clothes worn, a knapsack containing their worldly possessions, credentials when appropriate, and a money-belt. Most travel afoot, but nobles require a horse. A person's wealth is largely dependent on family wealth, which is relative to social status. The census data compiled by the crowns provide the following table and shows three levels of wealth within each social class. The value given amounts to what a person is assumed to possess when becoming of age, i.e. a responsible subject of the souvereign. This wealth may be used on items from the Price List on HârnPlayer and the Weapon and Armour tables. Estrangement can also influence funds.

Squires are traditionally equipped by their lord when knighted. This includes weapons, armour, and a good steed. Family wealth above does not include this. Very few Hârnic folk own property. Rural freemen and serfs rent cottages and land from the lord. City homes are mostly owned by a few wealthy folk and rented to poorer citizens. Only established urban guildsmen can hope to buy a private home. Most rural households own a few sheep or goats, perhaps a cow. Some families raise pigs which are prolific breeders. Wealthier households own oxen and rent them for village work in exchange for food and labor. Only the wealthiest of peasants can afford to keep a bull or a horse.

Clothes should suit a person’s station. A tunic, leggings, hat, and sandals are bare essentials. Some folk wear a robe or gown instead of a tunic. Travelers normally have a knapsack containing portable tools of their trade. A weaponcrafter, for example, must own hammers and tongs, but carrying an anvil is unlikely. Nearly everyone carries some fire-making tools (tinderbox, or flint and steel) and a strip of cloth for a towel, bandage, or arm-sling. A waterskin is also essential.

Nearly everyone owns a knife or dagger. Clubs, bows, hatchets, slings, and staves are also common. Other weapons are expensive and “Bearing Arms” in HârnPlayer should be consulted. Few young adults can afford good armour. Military individuals are mostly equipped by their unit, but knights on feudal service must bring their own weapons, armour, and steed.

Proving identity can be difficult on Hârn. A travelling person should have papers to prove guild rank (if any) and/or a letter of introduction from a prominent person such as a lord of the manor, or a cleric or sheriff, etc. Many guilds issue a badge or tattoo to prove rank. The expensive weapons and armour carried by knights speak for themselves.

People interested in a clerical career must visit a temple or abbey to be interviewed by the Master of Acolytes, or find a priest to sponsor the application. An appropriate Morality and a minimum Ritual knowledge are generally required, but a large donation to temple coffers may overcome a deficiency in talent. Acolyte training takes seven years. The church is a popular career for the second (or later) sons of nobility, or for devout characters of lesser birth. The complex mysteries of church doctrine are described in Religion.

Each church has holy scriptures written in a particular language and script: Churches teach this language and script to all Acolytes. Three churches perform their ceremonies and rituals in a private (secret) language in addition to their church language.

Newly ordained clerics start play knowing some Ritual Invocations. All Common invocations rated at Circle II are taught to clerics. Clerics may learn other invocations. Also see Religion. Clerics usually complete their training with little of material value. Acolytes are unpaid and the simple monastic life they lead in training does not encourage the accumulation of worldly goods. Newly ordained clerics typically own a wool robe, linen tunic and hose, leather sandals or boots, a dagger or staff, a simple ring denoting their status, and a purse of 6-36 pence.

Shek-Pvar belong to one of six ancient and esoteric sub-orders (convocations). Each convocation stresses on certain Pvaric principles because some conflict with others. Most Hârnic Shek-Pvar reside in Melderyn. Each convocation has its own chantries. Chantries vary in quality according to a five-star scale. The best are difficult to find and enter. A high Aura is required, but most applicants can improve their chance of acceptance if they have the right family connections, sufficient funds to bestow, or an appropriate recommendation.

ul.li: Lyahvi: Wind, Magnification, Visual Illusions
Peleahn: Fireballs, Volcanos, Movement Enhancement
Jmorvi: Weapon Creation, Prospecting/Mining, Lockboxes
Fyvria: Healing, Horticulture, Necromancy, Earthquakes
Odivshe: Waves, Precipitation, Movement Reduction
Savorya: Divination, Written Works, Memory Suppression
Neutral: Counter-Magic, Interworld Travel, Energy Storage

div.p: When Mavari learn how to attune to their element, they are taught to let a small amount of Principle exist within their Aura. Attunement must be done slowly and carefully, and it takes months before sufficient Principle can reside within the Aura to allow spells to be cast. Mages refer to this Aura-resident Principle as their Foundation. With time and practice, Foundations can be increased in size to accommodate Principle from other convocations. A gifted Mavari will sometimes join a convocation in opposition to his Sunsign. This gives him an advantage when learning spells of other convocations in the future, although it will impede his early career. A Shek-Pvar Satia-Mavari departs from their chantry after five to seven years apprenticeship.

A military career provides good weapon skills, useful social contacts, and a good opportunity for advancement in society. Of course, it might also be dangerous. Only individuals with good Strength, Stamina, and Will should consider this vocation. The sunsigns Ahnu, Angberelius, and Aralius are favored for warriors.

ul.li: Unarmoured Foot [UF] Unarmoured foot are most often found in Militia formations. Such troops wear ordinary clothing and may be equipped with homemade weapons.

Light Foot [LF] Typical light footmen wear incomplete leather and are equipped with a spear, shield, and a knife or dagger. Light foot are the fundamental troop type, and form the bulk of most standing armies.
Medium Foot [MF] Medium Foot have better weapons, most likely a spear, shortsword, shield, and better armour, perhaps some scale or mail. They are nearly always better trained and more experienced.

Heavy Foot [HF] The only permanent heavy foot found on Hârn are elite High Guard units within the dwarven army of Azadmere. Heavy foot carry heavy weapons like a battleaxe and are armoured with mail & quilt.
Unarmoured Horse [UH] Lightly armed troops used primarily for intelligence gathering, courier service, and light skirmishing.

Light Horse [LH] A light cavalryman is usually equipped with a lance or spear, shield, shortsword and mostly leather armour. He can be used in the same role as unarmoured horse, or used en masse in battle.
Medium Horse [MH] Riders are well-armoured in scale/mail with a good assortment of weapons. In feudal societies, medium horsemen are invariably knights or squires.

Heavy Horse [HH] The heavy cavalryman has well-padded mail from head to foot and may have strategically located plate. He carries lance, sword, and shield, and usually other weapons as well. Heavy horsemen are almost always noble and are primarily used as shock cavalry on the battlefield.
Shortbow [SB] A light footman equipped with a shortbow, and bearing light melee weapons and a roundshield or buckler.
Longbow [LB] A light footman equipped with a longbow. Longbowmen require years of training and are quite rare. They are well paid.

div.p: Because of the pervasive military influence of the Azeryan Empire, the Azeri names for military ranks are in common use throughout Northwestern Lythia.

Five enlisted ranks are in general use. These are rarely filled by nobles, who would consider them beneath their station. Molak: the common soldier. Status and remuneration vary according to special skills and unit type. Arkalin: commands a manus of five men; himself and four Molaks. Melbrin: commands a decad of ten men; himself, one Arkalin, and eight Molaks. Molarin: commands a company of twenty men; himself, one Melbrin, two Arkalins, and sixteen Molaks. A cavalry Molarin commands a squadron. Armolarin: the most senior Molarin in a centad. He is the principal liaison between officers and men, and is often the “real” commander of a Centad.

Officers are gentlemen. A commoner rising to officer rank is also invariably knighted. There is widespread belief that leaders must be noble, although there is no law to that effect. Five officer ranks exist. Hulhurin: junior staff officer, and deputy commander of a Centad. May also command an auxiliary company. Hethrin: commander of a Centad, or a Cohort staff officer. Kurlin: senior staff officer, and deputy commander of a Cohort. Berheth: commander of a Cohort. Tharin: commander of a Legion, which has two or more Cohorts.

Light horse units have the same ranks as infantry officers, except there is no Decad command. Medium and Heavy horse units differ at Manus and Squadron level. Chalisir: any trooper in a medium or heavy horse unit. A manus will be commanded by a senior Chalisir. Kephiri: commander of a Squadron of medium or heavy horse.

Most units let individuals enlist at age 16, and discourage those over 30. Interested individuals must contact a unit. The recruiting officer will ask about the person’s background, and military experience. A recommendation from someone in the unit might be helpful, and some Knight units (including the Khuzdul High Guard) require applicants to be noble.

Having completed four years of service, one may now elect to continue his military career or muster-out of the army to follow some other occupation. Guard and legionnaire units require a one year contract at the end of which a Re-enlistment Incentive may be offered to sign up for another twelve months. Irregular units have less formal contracts, most likely just a handshake or an oath, but the effect is the same.

Military wages are traditionally paid quarterly, but are listed monthly for comparison with other incomes. Considering the danger, wages are low, but armies offer various other benefits, and sometimes deliver them. These include food and shelter, and the opportunity to collect booty. The wage table gives monthly base pay. Elite units may get more, although some elite units in which men serve for honor may get less. It is not unusual for a soldier to work long stretches followed by long furloughs. Armies are generous with (unpaid) leave in peacetime. All foot units know the ranks Molak, Arkalin, Melbrin, Molarin, and Armolarin. The pay listed is for Molaks, every next rank has a pay increase of 1/4 over the previous rank on the Molak’s base. E.g. a Longbow Melbrin earns a monthly 108d. Light Horse units have the ranks Molak, Arkalin, Molarin, and Armolarin and progress 96d, 120d, 180d, and 216d. Medium and Heavy Horse units only have the ranks of Chalasir and Kephiri, of which the Kephiri earn +96d monthly over the base pay for Chalasirs.

Traditionally, a soldier may keep 2/3 of booty collected, giving 1/3 to the next highest rank, who gives 1/3 to the next highest rank, and so on. High ranking officers can get very rich with this scheme. Cash bonuses are sometimes given for long, distinguished service, or as a re-enlistment incentive. There is no typical amount, although a bonus would rarely exceed a month's pay.

Standing armies typically offer land grants to soldiers after twenty years service. Monetary pensions are rare, but “half-pay for life” might be awarded to a soldier who has distinguished himself in some way. When a soldier is maimed in the course of duty, he is discharged with a lump sum bonus rather than a pension. The amount is two to twelve months pay, depending on the nature of the injury and wealth of the unit. Few armies provide survivor benefits. A bonus of about six month's pay might be provided to a widow in exceptional cases. More commonly, the deceased's comrades will make a collection.

A cohort, ideally, consists of two centads of light foot, one of medium foot and one of light footbowmen (shortbow or longbow). In addition, there are often auxiliary units, such as companies of engineers (sappers), artillery (siege engines), light cavalry (scouts), medical, ostlers, weaponcrafters, etc.. In practice a Cohort may contain from two to six Centads, each consisting of two to eight Companies. The economic realities of manning, equipping, and supporting military units have always overwhelmed the neat organizational plans of staff officers. Each centad ideally has 100 men, grouped into 5 companies, lead by a Hethrin. Each company consists of 2 decads and each decad has 2 manus.

Some states, like Azeryan, group their cohorts into legions. The ideal Azeryani legion consists of four cohorts plus various auxiliary or reserve units attached to the legion HQ. On Hârn, legions exist only in the Thardic Republic where they tend to be little more than large cohorts.

Full strength cavalry cohorts are rare. It is simply too expensive to maintain such units in peacetime. The cohort shown, which exists only in the dreams of Lord Marshals, contains one centad of regular light horse, two centads of feudal medium horse, and one centad of feudal heavy horse. From mid-spring to mid-autumn, one or two squadrons of each feudal centad might be manned by knights doing their military service. Other squadrons would be inactive until a military emergency arises. Feudal units might be virtually devoid of personnel in winter. Formally., a squadron consists of 10 riders, and is split into two manus. Most cavalry tends to be deployed in small units of squadron or centad strength and massed only for battle. There are, of course, exceptions, such as the large bodies of horse defending Shorkyne and Trierzon's borders. Imperial cavalry tends to be mostly light. Azeryan, for example, uses cavalry in a supporting role (scouts and skirmishers), as does Tharda. This is mostly due to the lack of a feudal societal class. The Azeryani do, however, hire foreign knights to serve in some special forces. Logistical problems are different for cavalry units. Auxiliary forces, weaponcrafters, ostlers, transport, engineers, and the like are all slower than cavalry, and tend to get left behind. Units, even small ones, may have their own "field households" (messes) in tow. These too, may straggle.

Healing is a widely-practiced art. Clerics of Peoni have considerable medical expertise. Nearly all lay-folk, especially in rural areas, have some understanding of herbal remedies. Most warriors know emergency treatments for battlefield wounds.

Those who practice the healing arts full-time generally belong to the Society of Physicians, a loosely-organized guild. The Society does not care much about preserving its monopoly, and makes little attempt to maintain standards. Some masters are incompetent quacks, while others are highly-skilled surgeons. However, a physician who maims or kills too many patients will soon encounter difficulties from outraged friends and relatives.

Master physicians may take on as many apprentices as they wish. There are no journeymen in the Society, nor bonded masters in the normal sense; masters may take employment as they see fit. Many masters are associated with the church of Peoni, and some dabble in the arcane arts. Most physicians confine themselves to the treatment of minor ailments. Fees vary dramatically, sometimes according to the skill brought to bear, but mostly according to reputation. Fees typically range from 3d for fairly basic first aid to 240d for “major” surgery. Medicines, provided by the Apothecaries’ Guild, and hospital care (rare) can double or triple fees.

When people get sick or wounded, they are advised to get the best first aid available, and then seek someone with a decent Physician Mastery as soon as possible. Carrying a good supply of bandages and herbal remedies is always a good idea. Hârnic doctors are far more competent than their medieval Terran colleagues. They know, for example, it’s a good idea to keep open wounds and surgical instruments as clean as possible, although they do not know why. One theory has to do with fiery, invisible elementals which can be driven off with hot water. If no doctor is available any friend can administer treatment and self-treatment is always possible (modified by Will at GM discretion).

Esoteric Medical Treatments exist. Spells: For information on magical healing, see HârnMaster Magic. Rituals: For information on divine and cleric healing, see Religion. Psionics: For information on Psionic healing, see Psionics.

ul.li: Amputate: Surgical amputation is the only treatment for Grievous Frost and may be used to halt infection spreading. The afflicted body part is removed, but a new Serious or Grievous wound is created according to the operation’s success.
Bleeder: Treatment must be continued until bleeding stops. The patient may die under treatment.
Clean and Dress: Takes a few minutes and requires water and bandages.
Compress: Apply cold compress for several minutes. Herbal remedies and balms reduce swelling.
Splint: Setting bone and splinting. Takes several minutes.

Surgery: Includes cleaning and dressing the wound. Takes up to an hour. Requires sharp knives, and a needle and thread for sutures. Anesthetic is highly recommended (patients tend to struggle and whimper otherwise) and disinfectants are a good idea too. Such items may be purchased from good apothecaries and improve Treatment.
Warming: Gentle warming (blanket, healthy person’s flesh, etc.) of the injury for a few hours.

div.p: Psionic talents are native, psychic abilities some people possess, but may be unaware of. Since it requires years of practice to properly employ Psionic talents, they are within the sphere of the Guild of Arcane Lore. Those endowed may notice some of the odd effects produced by their latent Psionic abilities to level * (one the five-star scale). Some learn of their ability when another person with a developed talent is able to sense and inform them of its presence. Some talents are never discovered and remain dormant forever. Individuals who wish to became a mage are more likely to be accepted as an apprentice if they have an active Psionic talent.

Psionic Talents at one star are dormant. Anyone with a dormant talent is unaware of its existence. No conscious development of dormant talents is possible. However, exposure to powerful Psionic events or artifacts may stimulate a dormant talent. Once the talent exceeds *, it becomes known to the person possessing it. A dormant talent may reveal its nature with Psionic Episodes. In later parts of the dormant stage, frequent Psionic episodes can lead to apprehensions that the person is insane, and may cause well-meaning observers to attempt cures or confinement. This can be awkward when the person does not know the cause of the problem.

Once a talent develops past the dormant stage, it may be developed more or less normally. The individual must meditate (not sleep!) for at least 8 hours of a day to gain new insights. Anyone with an active Psionic talent can attempt to use it at anytime, provided the character is conscious. Using Psionic talents is tiring, regardless, whether or not the attempt is successful. Fatigue can also be accumulated after a Psionic episode. Particularly stressing invocations may cause the invoker to fall unconscious and also suffers Psionic Blindness, the complete inability to use any Psionic talent, for several hours. Sometimes unpredictable and/or unanticipated results may occur when invoking a Psionic talent. Possibilities for misfires are given in the talent descriptions. Psionic episodes occur randomly but are more likely, when a talent is used often or for extended periods of time.

Medium, Prescience, and Sensitivity are talents which may be stimulated by appropriate phenomena, which is called passive triggering. Medium may be triggered by the presence of ethereals, Prescience by imminent danger, and Sensitivity by a Psionic or magical residue/effect. If the stimulus is weak, the character is less likely to be alerted. When passive triggering occurs, the owner is given minimal information. If the character wants more information, the talent must be used actively (with fatigue being a consequence).

Two people with the same Psionic talent may wish to pool their efforts in invoking the talent. This may be done if skin contact is established by grasping hands, etc. and skin contact is maintained during the time spent invoking the talent. Under unknown circumstances ritual procedure may need to be followed in order to form the necessary “fusion” between invokers. This will become known to the affected invokers instinctively.

The following talents are known by the guild. No percentages are given, because talents are too rare to gather sufficient statistics. While Psionics are more instinctive than spells, concepts such as Spellfire Timing, Modeling, Detection, Noise, and Foci, all have application.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Brief hallucinations or illusions, headaches in nearby persons, sudden dizziness, people having bad luck or unusual clumsiness in the invoker’s presence.
Misfire: The invoker, or a random person/animal nearby, suffers the talent’s effect. Sometimes the invoker gets a severe headache instead.

div.p: A Psionic talent to influence the mind of another person (victim). The usual effect is to “freeze” the victim in place for a limited period of time. In order to invoke the talent successfully, eye contact between the invoker and the victim is necessary, but only for a momentary glance. The maximum distance at which effective eye contact can occur is approximately 10 yards. The effect remains in place until the attacker stops gazing at the victim.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Vivid dreams of faraway people and things. Dizziness, disorientation, confusion, headaches, sleepwalking, blurred vision, or mirage-like hallucinations can also occur.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the clairvoyant. Sometimes, severe headaches that cause temporary blindness occurs.

div.p: The ability to visualize events currently occurring at a remote location. A target may sense the attention of a clairvoyant. The psychic enters a trance and after the first minute gets a clear image of some object, person, or location that he is familiar with. The image may be moving and is of the current state. Sensory perception is normal but with narrow focus on the object. Clairvoyance may be used in either of two ways: Near: The clairvoyant enters a trance to transfer their point of perception to a location. The location must be familiar to the clairvoyant. Far: The clairvoyant enters a trance sand attempts to focus on a specific, remote person or object whose location may not be known. The clairvoyant does this by visualizing the person’s face (or by describing the object). There are no range restrictions, but there is also no chance to listen or smell.
